body: I've done some additional research and I've found that the problem is caused by LoopContext returning wrong length when iterating over a list iterator. Here is an example: ``` {% for item in menu('main') %} {{ item.title }} {% endfor %} ``` Where `menu('main')` returns an object with `__iter__` method which returns a new list iterator. In Jinja2 2.6 it works like it should. I can (and will) update my code to work with 2.7, but this is still a regression.
Do you have an exact testcase to reproduce?
Just to confirm: I cannot reproduce this currently.

Hi,

I think the problem is caused by accessing item from iterator before getting the length of it. In my example I've already retrieved first item from iterator before checking revindex0 so iterator has now 1 element less and length is smaller by 1.

I've fixed my problem by adding `__len__` method to object returned by `menu('main')` so loop context doesn't need to get the length from the iterator, as it knows how many items are there to display.

I'll try to reproduce this later (I've already modified my testcase) and I'll post it.

Just had the same problem:

```
from jinja2 import Environment
TMPL = "{% for item in items %}({{ loop.revindex }}, {{ loop.revindex0 }}){% endfor %}"
print Environment().from_string(TMPL).render(items=reversed(range(10)))
```

Just had the same problem with an iterator. {% for i in revisions|reverse %}
  • {{ loop.revindex }}
    • {% endfor %}     For loop.revindex it gives me a list ending with 0, for loop.revindex0 it gives me a list ending with -1 UPDATE: Looks like its only behaving like that in combination with the |reverse filter. The loop.length is when using |reverse also wrong

I don't think this is quite right yet. It seems that `loop.length` is off by one with reversed lists of length > 1. Example:

``` python
import jinja2

l = [0, 1, 2]
template_forward = jinja2.Template('{% for i in l %}{{ loop.length }} {% endfor %}')
template_reverse = jinja2.Template('{% for i in l|reverse %}{{ loop.length }} {% endfor %}')
print(template_forward.render(l=l))
print(template_reverse.render(l=l))
```

prints:

```
2 2 2
3 3 3
```

It should be `3 3 3` both times as the list clearly has three items in it.

Are you sure you are using current trunk? I get `3 3 3` for both.

... but, I just saw that It's wrong for lists of length < 2 :/
Ah yes I see this too. I was working from 2.7.3. Haha so my conclusion was correct even if my justification wasn't.

This appears to be still wrong when length of the iterator/sequence is 1:
```python
 >>> jinja2.Template("{% for i in lst|reverse %}{{ loop.revindex }}:{{ i }}, {% endfor %}").render(lst=[10,11])
'2:11, 1:10, '

>>> jinja2.Template("{% for i in lst|reverse %}{{ loop.revindex }}:{{ i }}, {% endfor %}").render(lst=[10])
'2:10, '
```
(Should be `1:10, `)
Please open a new issue to track this.

issue.title: Loop properties revindex and revindex0 still wrong in Jinja2 2.10

repository.name: jinja
repository.description: A very fast and expressive template engine.

issue.body:
## Expected Behavior
`loop.revindex` should be 1 when using a reversed iterator of length 1
```python
jinja2.Template("{% for i in lst|reverse %}{{ loop.revindex }}:{{ i }}, {% endfor %}")
      .render(lst=[10])
```
should print out: `'1:10, '`

## Actual Behavior
The index of the only iteration is set to 2
```python
jinja2.Template("{% for i in lst|reverse %}{{ loop.revindex }}:{{ i }}, {% endfor %}")
      .render(lst=[10])
```
prints out: `'2:10, '`

**However**:
```python
jinja2.Template("{% for i in lst|reverse %}{{ loop.revindex }}:{{ i }}, {% endfor %}")
      .render(lst=[10, 11])
```
correctly prints out: `'2:11, 1:10, '`

## Template Code
```jinja
{% for i in lst|reverse %}{{ loop.revindex }}:{{ i }}, {% endfor %}
```

## Your Environment
* Python version: 3.6.4
* Jinja version: 2.10

issue.title: Fix issue 794

repository.name: jinja

issue.body: This pull request fixes an issue https://github.com/pallets/jinja/issues/794, https://github.com/pallets/jinja/issues/244, https://github.com/pallets/jinja/issues/751 and issues related to revindex and length of iterable objects
